Dave -

Interesting -- I'm still getting the problem, even when I use spaces 
(or when I have only a single item), for instance:

>> setmassfractions(GAS_OBJECT, 'H2:1')
[...]
                           X                 Y   
                     -------------     ------------ 
                H2   9.694626e-001     6.666667e-001
                 H   0.000000e+000     0.000000e+000
                 O   0.000000e+000     0.000000e+000
                O2   3.053740e-002     3.333333e-001
                OH   0.000000e+000     0.000000e+000
[...]

>> setmassfractions(GAS_OBJECT, 'H2:1 H:1')
[...]
                           X                 Y   
                     -------------     ------------ 
                H2   3.264775e-001     3.333333e-001
                 H   6.529549e-001     3.333333e-001
                 O   0.000000e+000     0.000000e+000
                O2   2.056763e-002     3.333333e-001
                OH   0.000000e+000     0.000000e+000
[...]

So that doesn't seem to be working as a workaround for me.

(Also, for the molefractions function, the parser seems to work well 
even without the spaces; is this a different parser?)

- Brooks



--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, David Goodwin <dgoodwin@c...> wrote:
> Brooks -
> 
> The problem is that the parser code for some reason requires the  
> composition string to have a space after the commas between species. 
 
> Actually the comma is optional but the space isn't. The space 
shouldn't 
> be required, but it is at present. I always punctuate these strings 
> with a space by habit, and so didn't catch this problem with the 
> composition string parser.
> 
> If anyone wants to look into this problem and recommend a fix, the 
> parsing is done by function 'parseCompString' in file 
> 'stringUtils.cpp'.
> 
> Dave
